titleStmt.title: Despatch from J. Broadhurst to William H. Seward, July 12, 1877

bibl.title: Despatch from J. Broadhurst to William H. Seward
Despatches from United States Consuls in Sierra Leone, 1858-1906 T-438

div1.p:
United States Consulate
Sierra Leone 12th July 1877

Referring you to my dispatch dated 12th instant and numbered No 18 with reference to the forwarding to Liverpool of four destitute seamen forming part of the crew of the American bark Sterling whereof John Harlin was lately master:

I have now the honor to report having forwarded today per American bark "Jasker" A. M. Miller master, to the port of New York, two more of the crew of the above mentioned bark "Sterling", named respectively Allan Goldsmith and Albert Thompson

Also by the same vessel one Erik Nyberg lately belonging to the Crew of the
The honble W. H. Seward
Acting Secretary of State
Washington
the American bark "Greyhound" of Salem, Mass: who had him discharged from the said vessel and being destitute became chargeable to the consulate.

The Master of the Bark "Jasper" is provided with the proper certificate as required by Section 164 of the consular regulations, entitling him as the same being duly countersigned by the Collector of Customs in New York to the sum of Thirty dollars, being Ten dollars for cash of the above mentioned destitute mariners.

I have the honor to remain
Sir
Your humble obedt Servt
J Broadhurst
for James Frame Acting Consul
